sn47.51-62:0.3.eng: Twelve Discourses on the Ganges River, Etc.

sn47.51-62:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn47.51-62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn47.51-62:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn47.51-62:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn47.51-62:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn47.51-62:2.1.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn47.51-62:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.51-62:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.51-62:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.51-62:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.51-62:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.51-62:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bhāvento cattāro satipaṭṭhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
sn47.51-62:2.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four kinds of mindfulness meditation slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn47.51-62:3.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn47.51-62:3.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn47.51-62:3.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn47.6:1.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ sahasā ajjhappattā aggahesi.
sn47.6:1.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a hawk suddenly swooped down and grabbed a quail.

sn47.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, lāpo sakuṇo sakuṇagghiyā hariyamāno evaṃ paridevasi:
sn47.6:1.2.eng: And as the quail was being carried off he wailed,

sn47.6:1.3.pli: ‘mayamevamha alakkhikā, mayaṃ appapuññā, ye mayaṃ agocare carimha paravisaye.
sn47.6:1.3.eng: ‘I’m so unlucky, so unfortunate, to have roamed out of my territory into the domain of others.

sn47.6:1.4.pli: Sacejja mayaṃ gocare careyyāma sake pettike visaye, na myāyaṃ, sakuṇagghi, alaṃ abhavissa, yadidaṃ—yuddhāyā’ti.
sn47.6:1.4.eng: If today I’d roamed within my own territory, the domain of my fathers, this hawk wouldn’t have been able to beat me by fighting.’

sn47.6:1.5.pli: ‘Ko pana te, lāpa, gocaro sako pettiko visayo’ti?
sn47.6:1.5.eng: ‘So, quail, what is your own territory, the domain of your fathers?’

sn47.6:1.6.eng: ‘It’s a ploughed field covered with clods of earth.’

sn47.6:1.7.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi sake bale apatthaddhā sake bale asaṃvadamānā lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ pamuñci:
sn47.6:1.7.eng: Confident in her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She released the quail, saying,

sn47.6:1.8.pli: ‘gaccha kho tvaṃ, lāpa, tatrapi me gantvā na mokkhasī’ti.
sn47.6:1.8.eng: ‘Go now, quail. But even there you won’t escape me!’

sn47.6:2.1.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, lāpo sakuṇo naṅgalakaṭṭhakaraṇaṃ leḍḍuṭṭhānaṃ gantvā mahantaṃ leḍḍuṃ abhiruhitvā sakuṇagghiṃ vadamāno aṭṭhāsi:
sn47.6:2.1.eng: Then the quail went to a ploughed field covered with clods of earth. He climbed up a big clod, and standing there, he said to the hawk:

sn47.6:2.2.pli: ‘ehi kho dāni me, sakuṇagghi, ehi kho dāni me, sakuṇagghī’ti.
sn47.6:2.2.eng: ‘Come get me, hawk! Come get me, hawk!’

sn47.6:2.3.pli: Atha kho sā, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi sake bale apatthaddhā sake bale asaṃvadamānā ubho pakkhe sannayha lāpaṃ sakuṇaṃ sahasā ajjhappattā.
sn47.6:2.3.eng: Confident in her own strength, the hawk was not daunted or intimidated. She folded her wings and suddenly swooped down on the quail.

sn47.6:2.4.pli: Yadā kho, bhikkhave, aññāsi lāpo sakuṇo ‘bahuāgato kho myāyaṃ sakuṇagghī’ti, atha tasseva leḍḍussa antaraṃ paccupādi.
sn47.6:2.4.eng: When the quail knew that the hawk was nearly there, he slipped under that clod.

sn47.6:2.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakuṇagghi tattheva uraṃ paccatāḷesi.
sn47.6:2.5.eng: But the hawk crashed chest-first right there.

sn47.6:2.6.pli: Evañhi taṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yo agocare carati paravisaye.
sn47.6:2.6.eng: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.

sn47.6:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, mā agocare carittha paravisaye.
sn47.6:3.1.eng: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.

sn47.6:3.2.pli: Agocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ paravisaye lacchati māro otāraṃ, lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
sn47.6:3.2.eng: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will find a vulnerability and get an opportunity.

sn47.6:3.3.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo?
sn47.6:3.3.eng: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?

sn47.6:3.4.eng: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn47.6:3.6.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
sn47.6:3.6.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn47.6:3.10.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
sn47.6:3.10.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn47.6:3.11.eng: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.

sn47.6:4.1.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
sn47.6:4.1.eng: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

sn47.6:4.2.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṃ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
sn47.6:4.2.eng: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t find a vulnerability or get an opportunity.

sn47.6:4.3.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo?
sn47.6:4.3.eng: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?

sn47.6:4.5.eng: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.6:4.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.6:4.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.6:4.8.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.6:4.10.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ—
sn47.6:4.10.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.6:4.11.pli: ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo”ti.
sn47.6:4.11.eng: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”

sn47.63-72:1.1.pli: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā”ti
sn47.63-72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet …”

sn47.63-72:2.1.eng: The Realized One, footprint, roof peak,

sn47.7:1.1.pli: “Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa duggā visamā desā, yattha neva makkaṭānaṃ cārī na manussānaṃ.
sn47.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, in the Himalayas there are regions that are rugged and impassable. In some such regions, neither monkeys nor humans can go,

sn47.7:1.2.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa duggā visamā desā, yattha makkaṭānañhi kho cārī, na manussānaṃ.
sn47.7:1.2.eng: while in others, monkeys can go but not humans.

sn47.7:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, himavato pabbatarājassa samā bhūmibhāgā ramaṇīyā, yattha makkaṭānañceva cārī manussānañca.
sn47.7:1.3.eng: There are also level, pleasant places where both monkeys and humans can go.

sn47.7:1.4.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, luddā makkaṭavīthīsu lepaṃ oḍḍenti makkaṭānaṃ bādhanāya.
sn47.7:1.4.eng: There hunters lay snares of tar on the monkey trails to catch the monkeys.

sn47.7:2.1.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, ye te makkaṭā abālajātikā alolajātikā, te taṃ lepaṃ disvā ārakā parivajjanti.
sn47.7:2.1.eng: The monkeys who are not foolhardy and reckless see the tar and avoid it from afar.

sn47.7:2.2.pli: Yo pana so hoti makkaṭo bālajātiko lolajātiko, so taṃ lepaṃ upasaṅkamitvā hatthena gaṇhāti.
sn47.7:2.2.eng: But a foolish and reckless monkey goes up to the tar and grabs it with a hand.

sn47.7:2.4.eng: Thinking to free his hand, he grabs it with his other hand.

sn47.7:2.6.eng: Thinking to free both hands, he grabs it with a foot.

sn47.7:2.8.pli: ‘Ubho hatthe mocessāmi pādañcā’ti dutiyena pādena gaṇhāti.
sn47.7:2.8.eng: Thinking to free both hands and foot, he grabs it with his other foot.

sn47.7:2.10.pli: ‘Ubho hatthe mocessāmi pāde cā’ti tuṇḍena gaṇhāti.
sn47.7:2.10.eng: Thinking to free both hands and feet, he grabs it with his snout.

sn47.7:2.12.pli: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, makkaṭo pañcoḍḍito thunaṃ seti anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo luddassa.
sn47.7:2.12.eng: And so the monkey, trapped at five points, just lies there screeching. He’d meet with tragedy and disaster, and the hunter can do what he wants with him.

sn47.7:2.13.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, luddo vijjhitvā tasmiṃyeva kaṭṭhakataṅgāre avassajjetvā yena kāmaṃ pakkamati.
sn47.7:2.13.eng: The hunter spears him, pries him off that tarred block of wood, and goes wherever he wants.

sn47.7:2.14.pli: Evaṃ so taṃ, bhikkhave, hoti yo agocare carati paravisaye.
sn47.7:2.14.eng: That’s what happens when you roam out of your territory into the domain of others.

sn47.7:3.1.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, mā agocare carittha paravisaye.
sn47.7:3.1.eng: So, mendicants, don’t roam out of your own territory into the domain of others.

sn47.7:3.2.pli: Agocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ paravisaye lacchati māro otāraṃ, lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
sn47.7:3.2.eng: If you roam out of your own territory into the domain of others, Māra will find a vulnerability and get an opportunity.

sn47.7:3.3.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno agocaro paravisayo?
sn47.7:3.3.eng: And what is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others?

sn47.7:3.5.eng: It’s the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn47.7:3.7.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
sn47.7:3.7.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn47.7:3.11.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā.
sn47.7:3.11.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn47.7:3.12.eng: This is not a mendicant’s own territory but the domain of others.

sn47.7:4.1.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, caratha sake pettike visaye.
sn47.7:4.1.eng: You should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.

sn47.7:4.2.pli: Gocare, bhikkhave, carataṃ sake pettike visaye na lacchati māro otāraṃ, na lacchati māro ārammaṇaṃ.
sn47.7:4.2.eng: If you roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers, Māra won’t find a vulnerability and get an opportunity.

sn47.7:4.3.pli: Ko ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo?
sn47.7:4.3.eng: And what is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers?

sn47.7:4.5.eng: It’s the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn47.7:4.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.7:4.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.7:4.8.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.7:4.10.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.7:4.10.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.7:4.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno gocaro sako pettiko visayo”ti.
sn47.7:4.11.eng: This is a mendicant’s own territory, the domain of the fathers.”

sn47.73-84:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyantī”ti
sn47.73-84:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, all the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth. …”

sn47.73-84:2.2.eng: a tree, a pot, and a spike,

sn47.73-84:2.3.eng: the atmosphere, and two on clouds,

sn47.73-84:2.4.eng: a ship, a guest house, and a river.

sn47.8:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo sūdo rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattaṃ vā nānaccayehi sūpehi paccupaṭṭhito assa—
sn47.8:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose a foolish, incompetent, unskillful cook was to serve a ruler or their chief minister with an extravagant variety of curries:

sn47.8:1.2.pli: ambilaggehipi, tittakaggehipi, kaṭukaggehipi, madhuraggehipi, khārikehipi, akhārikehipi, loṇikehipi, aloṇikehipi.
sn47.8:1.2.eng: superbly sour, bitter, pungent, and sweet; hot and mild, and salty and bland.

sn47.8:2.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo sūdo sakassa bhattu nimittaṃ na uggaṇhāti:
sn47.8:2.1.eng: But that cook didn’t take their master’s hint:

sn47.8:2.2.pli: ‘idaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, imassa vā abhiharati, imassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, imassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn47.8:2.2.eng: ‘Today my master preferred this sauce, or he reached for it, or he took a lot of it, or he praised it.

sn47.8:2.3.pli: Ambilaggaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, ambilaggassa vā abhiharati, ambilaggassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, ambilaggassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Tittakaggaṃ vā me ajja … kaṭukaggaṃ vā me ajja … madhuraggaṃ vā me ajja … khārikaṃ vā me ajja … akhārikaṃ vā me ajja … loṇikaṃ vā me ajja … aloṇikaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, aloṇikassa vā abhiharati, aloṇikassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, aloṇikassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī’ti.
sn47.8:2.3.eng: Today my master preferred the sour or bitter or pungent or sweet or hot or mild or salty sauce. Or he preferred the bland sauce, or he reached for the bland one, or he took a lot of it, or he praised it.’

sn47.8:3.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo sūdo na ceva lābhī hoti acchādanassa, na lābhī vetanassa, na lābhī abhihārānaṃ.
sn47.8:3.1.eng: That foolish, incompetent, unskillful cook doesn’t get presented with clothes, wages, or bonuses.

sn47.8:3.3.pli: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo sūdo sakassa bhattu nimittaṃ na uggaṇhāti.
sn47.8:3.3.eng: Because they don’t take their master’s hint.

sn47.8:3.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bālo abyatto akusalo bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.8:3.4.eng: In the same way, a foolish, incompetent, unskillful mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.8:3.5.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato cittaṃ na samādhiyati, upakkilesā na pahīyanti.
sn47.8:3.5.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, their mind doesn’t enter immersion, and their corruptions aren’t given up.

sn47.8:3.6.eng: But they don’t take the hint.

sn47.8:3.7.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.8:3.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.8:3.9.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.8:3.10.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato cittaṃ na samādhiyati, upakkilesā na pahīyanti.
sn47.8:3.10.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, the mind doesn’t enter immersion, and the corruptions aren’t given up.

sn47.8:3.11.eng: But they don’t take the hint.

sn47.8:4.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo bhikkhu na ceva lābhī hoti diṭṭheva dhamme sukhavihārānaṃ, na lābhī satisampajaññassa.
sn47.8:4.1.eng: That foolish, incompetent, unskillful mendicant doesn’t get blissful meditations in this very life, nor do they get mindfulness and situational awareness.

sn47.8:4.3.pli: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, bālo abyatto akusalo bhikkhu sakassa cittassa nimittaṃ na uggaṇhāti.
sn47.8:4.3.eng: Because they don’t take their mind’s hint.

sn47.8:5.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo sūdo rājānaṃ vā rājamahāmattaṃ vā nānaccayehi sūpehi paccupaṭṭhito assa—
sn47.8:5.1.eng: Suppose an astute, competent, skillful cook was to serve a ruler or their chief minister with an extravagant variety of curries:

sn47.8:5.2.pli: ambilaggehipi, tittakaggehipi, kaṭukaggehipi, madhuraggehipi, khārikehipi, akhārikehipi, loṇikehipi, aloṇikehipi.
sn47.8:5.2.eng: superbly sour, bitter, pungent, and sweet; hot and mild, and salty and bland.

sn47.8:6.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo sūdo sakassa bhattu nimittaṃ uggaṇhāti:
sn47.8:6.1.eng: And that cook took their master’s hint:

sn47.8:6.2.pli: ‘idaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, imassa vā abhiharati, imassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, imassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati.
sn47.8:6.2.eng: ‘Today my master preferred this sauce, or he reached for it, or he took a lot of it, or he praised it.

sn47.8:6.3.pli: Ambilaggaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, ambilaggassa vā abhiharati, ambilaggassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, ambilaggassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Tittakaggaṃ vā me ajja … kaṭukaggaṃ vā me ajja … madhuraggaṃ vā me ajja … khārikaṃ vā me ajja … akhārikaṃ vā me ajja … loṇikaṃ vā me ajja … aloṇikaṃ vā me ajja bhattu sūpeyyaṃ ruccati, aloṇikassa vā abhiharati, aloṇikassa vā bahuṃ gaṇhāti, aloṇikassa vā vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatī’ti.
sn47.8:6.3.eng: Today my master preferred the sour or bitter or pungent or sweet or hot or mild or salty sauce. Or he preferred the bland sauce, or he reached for the bland one, or he took a lot of it, or he praised it.’

sn47.8:7.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo sūdo lābhī ceva hoti acchādanassa, lābhī vetanassa, lābhī abhihārānaṃ.
sn47.8:7.1.eng: That astute, competent, skillful cook gets presented with clothes, wages, and bonuses.

sn47.8:7.3.pli: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo sūdo sakassa bhattu nimittaṃ uggaṇhāti.
sn47.8:7.3.eng: Because they take their master’s hint.

sn47.8:7.4.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco paṇḍito byatto kusalo bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.8:7.4.eng: In the same way, an astute, competent, skillful mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.8:7.5.pli: Tassa kāye kāyānupassino viharato cittaṃ samādhiyati, upakkilesā pahīyanti.
sn47.8:7.5.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of the body, their mind enters immersion, and their corruptions are given up.

sn47.8:7.7.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.8:7.9.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.8:7.9.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.8:7.10.pli: Tassa dhammesu dhammānupassino viharato cittaṃ samādhiyati, upakkilesā pahīyanti.
sn47.8:7.10.eng: As they meditate observing an aspect of principles, their mind enters immersion, and their corruptions are given up.

sn47.8:8.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo bhikkhu lābhī ceva hoti diṭṭheva dhamme sukhavihārānaṃ, lābhī hoti satisampajaññassa.
sn47.8:8.1.eng: That astute, competent, skillful mendicant gets blissful meditations in this very life, and they get mindfulness and situational awareness.

sn47.8:8.3.pli: Tathā hi so, bhikkhave, paṇḍito byatto kusalo bhikkhu sakassa cittassa nimittaṃ uggaṇhātī”ti.
sn47.8:8.3.eng: Because they take their mind’s hint.”

sn47.85-94:1.3.eng: The search for sensual pleasures, the search for continued existence, and the search for a spiritual path. …”

sn47.85-94:2.2.eng: states of existence, three kinds of suffering,

sn47.9:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati veḷuvagāmake.
sn47.9:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the little village of Beluva.

sn47.9:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn47.9:1.4.pli: “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, samantā vesāliyā yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upetha.
sn47.9:1.4.eng: “Mendicants, please enter the rainy season residence with whatever friends or acquaintances you have around Vesālī.

sn47.9:1.5.eng: I’ll commence the rainy season residence right here in the little village of Beluva.”

sn47.9:1.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā samantā vesāliyā yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upagacchuṃ.
sn47.9:1.6.eng: “Yes, sir,” those mendicants replied. They did as the Buddha said,

sn47.9:1.7.pli: Bhagavā pana tattheva veḷuvagāmake vassaṃ upagacchi.
sn47.9:1.7.eng: while the Buddha commenced the rainy season residence right there in the little village of Beluva.

sn47.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato vassūpagatassa kharo ābādho uppajji, bāḷhā vedanā vattanti māraṇantikā.
sn47.9:2.1.eng: After the Buddha had commenced the rainy season residence, he fell severely ill, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.

sn47.9:2.2.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāsesi avihaññamāno.
sn47.9:2.2.eng: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.

sn47.9:2.3.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha:

sn47.9:2.4.pli: “na kho me taṃ patirūpaṃ, yohaṃ anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parinibbāyeyyaṃ.
sn47.9:2.4.eng: “It would not be appropriate for me to be fully extinguished before informing my attendants and taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn47.9:2.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihareyyan”ti.
sn47.9:2.5.eng: Why don’t I forcefully suppress this illness, stabilize the life force, and live on?”

sn47.9:2.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihāsi.
sn47.9:2.6.eng: So that is what he did.

sn47.9:2.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavato so ābādho paṭippassambhi.
sn47.9:2.7.eng: Then the Buddha’s illness died down.

sn47.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā vihārā nikkhamitvā vihārapacchāyāyaṃ paññatte āsane nisīdi.
sn47.9:3.1.eng: Soon after the Buddha had recovered from that sickness, he left his dwelling and sat in the shade of the porch on the seat spread out.

sn47.9:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn47.9:3.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn47.9:3.3.eng: “Sir, it’s fantastic that the Buddha is comfortable,

sn47.9:3.6.pli: Api ca me, bhante, madhurakajāto viya kāyo, disāpi me na pakkhāyanti, dhammāpi maṃ nappaṭibhanti bhagavato gelaññena.
sn47.9:3.6.eng: Because when the Buddha was sick, my body felt like it was drugged. I was disorientated, and the teachings didn’t spring to mind.

sn47.9:3.7.pli: Api ca me, bhante, ahosi kācideva assāsamattā:
sn47.9:3.7.eng: Still, at least I was consoled by the thought that

sn47.9:3.8.pli: ‘na tāva bhagavā parinibbāyissati, na yāva bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharatī’”ti.
sn47.9:3.8.eng: the Buddha won’t be fully extinguished without bringing something up regarding the Saṅgha of mendicants.”

sn47.9:4.1.pli: “Kiṃ pana dāni, ānanda, bhikkhusaṅgho mayi paccāsīsati?
sn47.9:4.1.eng: “But what could the mendicant Saṅgha expect from me now, Ānanda?

sn47.9:4.2.pli: Desito, ānanda, mayā dhammo anantaraṃ abāhiraṃ karitvā.
sn47.9:4.2.eng: I’ve taught the Dhamma without making any distinction between secret and public teachings.

sn47.9:4.3.eng: The Realized One doesn’t have the closed fist of a tutor when it comes to the teachings.

sn47.9:4.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pariharissāmī’ti vā, ‘mamuddesiko bhikkhusaṅgho’ti vā, so nūna, ānanda, bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāhareyya.
sn47.9:4.5.eng: ‘I shall lead the mendicant Saṅgha,’ or ‘the Saṅgha of mendicants is meant for me,’ let them bring something up regarding the Saṅgha.

sn47.9:4.6.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, na evaṃ hoti:
sn47.9:4.6.eng: But the Realized One doesn’t think like this,

sn47.9:4.8.pli: Sa kiṃ, ānanda, tathāgato bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharissati.
sn47.9:4.8.eng: so why should he bring something up regarding the Saṅgha?

sn47.9:4.9.pli: Etarahi kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
sn47.9:4.9.eng: Now I am old, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.

sn47.9:4.11.eng: Just as a decrepit old cart keeps going by relying on straps,

sn47.9:4.12.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, veḷamissakena maññe tathāgatassa kāyo yāpeti.
sn47.9:4.12.eng: in the same way, the Realized One’s body keeps going as if it were relying on straps.

sn47.9:5.1.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgato sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā ekaccānaṃ vedanānaṃ nirodhā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, phāsutaro, ānanda, tasmiṃ samaye tathāgatassa kāyo hoti.
sn47.9:5.1.eng: Sometimes the Realized One, not focusing on any signs, and with the cessation of certain feelings, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart. Only then does the Realized One’s body become more comfortable.

sn47.9:5.2.pli: Tasmātihānanda, attadīpā viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
sn47.9:5.2.eng: So Ānanda, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.9:6.1.pli: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
sn47.9:6.1.eng: And how does a mendicant do this?

sn47.9:6.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.9:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.9:6.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.9:6.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.9:6.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.9:6.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
sn47.9:6.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant lives as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

sn47.9:6.7.pli: Ye hi keci, ānanda, etarahi vā mamaccaye vā attadīpā viharissanti attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā; tamatagge mete, ānanda, bhikkhū bhavissanti ye keci sikkhākāmā”ti.
sn47.9:6.7.eng: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”

sn47.95-104:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn47.95-104:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn47.95-104:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn47.95-104:1.5.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn47.95-104:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.95-104:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.95-104:2.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn47.95-104:2.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.95-104:2.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.95-104:2.6.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
sn47.95-104:2.6.eng: These four kinds of mindfulness meditation should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn47.95-104:3.1.eng: (The Linked Discourses on Mindfulness Meditation should be told in full as in the Linked Discourses on the Path. These ten discourses correspond to SN 45.171–179, with the above as the final discourse.)

sn47.95-104:4.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on Mindfulness Meditation is the third section.
